metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Scope
Scope determines the accessibility (visibility) of variables.
content.html: Scope determines the accessibility (visibility) of variables.

content.text: JavaScript variables have 3 types of scope:
content.html: JavaScript variables have 3 types of scope:

content.text: Block Scope
Before ES6 (2015), JavaScript variables had only Global Scope and Function Scope .
content.html: Before ES6 (2015), JavaScript variables had only Global Scope and Function Scope.

content.text: ES6 introduced two important new JavaScript keywords: let and const .
content.html: ES6 introduced two important new JavaScript keywords: let and const.

content.text: These two keywords provide Block Scope in JavaScript.
content.html: These two keywords provide Block Scope in JavaScript.

content.text: Variables declared inside a { } block cannot be accessed from outside the block:
content.html: Variables declared inside a { } block cannot be accessed from outside the block:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // x can NOT be used here

syntax_highlighting.text: // x can NOT be used here

content.code_html:
{
  let x = 2;
}
// x can NOT be used here

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // x can NOT be used here

content.text: Variables declared with the var keyword can NOT have block scope.
content.html: Variables declared with the var keyword can NOT have block scope.

content.text: Variables declared inside a { } block can be accessed from outside the block.
content.html: Variables declared inside a { } block can be accessed from outside the block.

content.code_html:
{
  var x = 2;
}
// x CAN be used here

content.text: Local Scope
Variables declared within a JavaScript function, are LOCAL to the function:
content.html: Variables declared within a JavaScript function, are LOCAL to the function:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // code here can NOT use carName
// code here can NOT use carName

syntax_highlighting.text: // code here can NOT use carName
// code here can NOT use carName

content.code_html:
// code here can NOT use carName

function myFunction() {
  let carName = "Volvo";
  // code here CAN use carName
}

// code here can NOT use carName

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // code here can NOT use carName
// code here can NOT use carName

content.text: Local variables have Function Scope :
content.html: Local variables have Function Scope:

content.text: They can only be accessed from within the function.
content.html: They can only be accessed from within the function.

content.text: Since local variables are only recognized inside their functions, variables with the same name can be used in different functions.
content.html: Since local variables are only recognized inside their functions, variables with the same name can be used in different functions.

content.text: Local variables are created when a function starts, and deleted when the function is completed.
content.html: Local variables are created when a function starts, and deleted when the function is completed.

content.text: Function Scope
JavaScript has function scope: Each function creates a new scope.
content.html: JavaScript has function scope: Each function creates a new scope.

content.text: Variables defined inside a function are not accessible (visible) from outside the function.
content.html: Variables defined inside a function are not accessible (visible) from outside the function.

content.text: Variables declared with var , let and const are quite similar when declared inside a function.
content.html: Variables declared with var, let and const are quite similar when declared inside a function.

content.text: They all have Function Scope :
content.html: They all have Function Scope:

content.code_html:
function myFunction() {
  var carName = "Volvo";   // Function Scope
 }

function myFunction() {
  let carName = "Volvo";   // Function Scope
 }

function myFunction() {
  const carName = "Volvo";   // Function Scope
 }

content.text: Global JavaScript Variables
A variable declared outside a function, becomes GLOBAL .
content.html: A variable declared outside a function, becomes GLOBAL.

syntaxHighlighting.text: // code here can also use carName

syntax_highlighting.text: // code here can also use carName

content.code_html:
let carName = "Volvo";
// code here can use carName

function myFunction() {
// code here can also use carName
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // code here can also use carName

content.text: A global variable has Global Scope :
content.html: A global variable has Global Scope:

content.text: All scripts and functions on a web page can access it.
content.html: All scripts and functions on a web page can access it.

content.text: Global Scope
Variables declared Globally (outside any function) have Global Scope .
content.html: Variables declared Globally (outside any function) have Global Scope.

content.text: Global variables can be accessed from anywhere in a JavaScript program.
content.html: Global variables can be accessed from anywhere in a JavaScript program.

content.text: Variables declared with var , let and const are quite similar when declared outside a block.
content.html: Variables declared with var, let and const are quite similar when declared outside a block.

content.text: They all have Global Scope :
content.html: They all have Global Scope:

content.code_html: var x = 2;       // Global scope
let x = 2;       // Global scope
const x = 2;       // Global scope

content.text: JavaScript Variables
In JavaScript, objects and functions are also variables.
content.html: In JavaScript, objects and functions are also variables.

content.text: Scope determines the accessibility of variables, objects, and functions from different parts of the code.
content.html: Scope determines the accessibility of variables, objects, and functions from different parts of the code.

content.text: Automatically Global
If you assign a value to a variable that has not been declared, it will automatically become a GLOBAL variable.
content.html: If you assign a value to a variable that has not been declared, it will automatically become a GLOBAL variable.

content.text: This code example will declare a global variable carName , even if the value is assigned inside a function.
content.html: This code example will declare a global variable carName, even if the value is assigned inside a function.

content.code_html:
myFunction();

// code here can use carName

function myFunction() {
  carName = "Volvo";
}

content.text: Strict Mode
All modern browsers support running JavaScript in "Strict Mode".
content.html: All modern browsers support running JavaScript in "Strict Mode".

content.text: You will learn more about how to use strict mode in a later chapter of this tutorial.
content.html: You will learn more about how to use strict mode in a later chapter of this tutorial.

content.text: In "Strict Mode", undeclared variables are not automatically global.
content.html: In "Strict Mode", undeclared variables are not automatically global.

content.text: Global Variables in HTML
With JavaScript, the global scope is the JavaScript environment.
content.html: With JavaScript, the global scope is the JavaScript environment.

content.text: In HTML, the global scope is the window object.
content.html: In HTML, the global scope is the window object.

content.text: Global variables defined with the var keyword belong to the window object:
content.html: Global variables defined with the var keyword belong to the window object:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
var carName = "Volvo";// code here 
 can use window.carName

content.code:
var carName = "Volvo";// code here
can use window.carName

syntax_highlighting.text:
var carName = "Volvo";// code here 
 can use window.carName

content.code_html:
var carName = "Volvo";
// code here can use window.carName

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
var carName = "Volvo";// code here 
 can use window.carName

content.text: Global variables defined with the let keyword do not belong to the window object:
content.html: Global variables defined with the let keyword do not belong to the window object:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let carName = "Volvo";
// code here can not use window.carName
// code here can not use window.carName

content.code:
let carName = "Volvo";
// code here can not use window.carName

syntax_highlighting.text:
let carName = "Volvo";
// code here can not use window.carName
// code here can not use window.carName

content.code_html:
let carName = "Volvo";
// code here can not use window.carName

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let carName = "Volvo";
// code here can not use window.carName
// code here can not use window.carName

content.text: Warning
Do NOT create global variables unless you intend to.
content.html: Do NOT create global variables unless you intend to.

content.text: Your global variables (or functions) can overwrite window variables (or functions). Any function, including the window object, can overwrite your global variables and functions.
content.html:
Your global variables (or functions) can overwrite window variables (or functions).
Any function, including the window object, can overwrite your global variables and functions.

content.text: The Lifetime of JavaScript Variables
The lifetime of a JavaScript variable starts when it is declared.
content.html: The lifetime of a JavaScript variable starts when it is declared.

content.text: Function (local) variables are deleted when the function is completed.
content.html: Function (local) variables are deleted when the function is completed.

content.text: In a web browser, global variables are deleted when you close the browser window (or tab).
content.html: In a web browser, global variables are deleted when you close the browser window (or tab).

content.text: Function Arguments
Function arguments (parameters) work as local variables inside functions.
content.html: Function arguments (parameters) work as local variables inside functions.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Consider the following code: let x = 5; { let x = 3; } alert(x); What will be the alerted result?
content.html:
Consider the following code:
let x = 5;
{
  let x = 3;
}
alert(x);
What will be the alerted result?

metadata.question: Consider the following code:let x = 5;{  let x = 3;}alert(x);What will be the alerted result?

content.question: Consider the following code:let x = 5;{  let x = 3;}alert(x);What will be the alerted result?
